member.name: T:SUnit.Assert
member.summary: Contains methods for performing assertions. Every unit test framework has a class like this.

member.name: M:SUnit.Assert.That``1(``0)
member.summary: Used to specify the actual value when writing assertions. For example, Assert.That(2 + 2).Is.Not.EqualTo(5);.

member.name: T:SUnit.Assertions.ActualValueExpression`3
member.summary: A base class for implementing .
member.typeparam: This should be set to your own type, or an interface you implement.
The type of that is created by calling . Must be derived from .
member.remarks: Subclassing is very straightforward. Derived classes will have almost no logic in them. The main reason for subclassing in to allow specialization for certain types of actual value. For example, we want to support special operations such as Is.Empty for collections, and Is.True and Is.False for booleans.

member.name: M:SUnit.Assertions.ActualValueExpression`3.#ctor(`0,SUnit.Assertions.ConstraintModifier{`0})
member.summary: Creates a new for the specified actual value and with the specified constraint modifier.
member.param: The actual value that is under test.
A function to modify any constraints that are applied to the actual value.

member.name: M:SUnit.Assertions.ActualValueExpression`3.CreateTest(`0,SUnit.IConstraint{`0})
member.summary: When overridden in a derived class, creates a new by applying the specified constraint to the specified actual value.
member.param: The actual value that is being tested.
The constraint to apply to the actual value.
member.returns: An that applies the specified constraint to the specified actual value.

member.name: M:SUnit.Assertions.ActualValueExpression`3.CreateExpression(`0,SUnit.Assertions.ConstraintModifier{`0})
member.summary: When overridden in a derived class, creates a new with the specified actual value and the specified constraint modifier.
member.param: The actual value that is under test.
A function to modify any constraints that are applied.
member.returns: A new for the specified actual value and with the specified constraint modifier function.
member.remarks: This should simply be passing the arguments through to your own constructor, which in turn should just be passing the arguments to the base class constructor.

member.name: T:SUnit.Assertions.ActualValueTest`3
member.summary: Base class for a that is created by applying a to given actual value.
member.typeparam: The type of the actual value under test.
The type of that produced the test. This will be the return value of , , etc. to allow the user to chain multiple constraints on the same value.
The type of produced. This should be the most derived type that is publically visible of whatever is subclassing this class.

member.name: P:SUnit.Assertions.ActualValueTest`3.Passed
member.summary: Indicates whether the test passed.

member.summary: An expression that allows users to apply constraints to a supplied actual value. An example of an would be the property that's commonly used when creating assertions.
member.typeparam: The type of the actual value.
The type of the current . Please pretend that C# supports the Curiously Recurring Template Pattern and don't do anything funny.
The type of that is returned when a constraint is applied to the current .
